constant folding during the typer, we use the "typer-opaque constants"-trick and initially add `2**30-(c0&1)` instead of `2**30`; this will result in a final type of `Range(-1, 0)` instead of `Range(0, 0)` for `x`.<span class="line"><!---->To prevent constant folding during the typer, we use the "typer-opaque constants"-trick and initially add `2**30-(c0&amp;1)` instead of `2**30`; this will result in a final type of `Range(-1, 0)` instead of `Range(0, 0)` for `x`.<!----></span><br>To see that this is unproblematic look at the typer for `BitwiseAnd`-nodes (in `src/compiler/operation_typer.cc`:<span class="line"><!---->To see that this is unproblematic look at the typer for `BitwiseAnd`-nodes (in `src/compiler/operation_typer.cc`:<!----></span><br><br>```<span class="line"><!---->```<!----></span><br>Type OperationTyper::NumberBitwiseAnd(Type lhs, Type rhs) {<span class="line"><!---->Type OperationTyper::NumberBitwiseAnd(Type lhs, Type rhs) {<!----></span><br>  <span class="line"><!---->  <!----></span><br>  ...<span class="line"><!---->  ...<!----></span><br>  <span class="line"><!---->  <!----></span><br>  double min = kMinInt;<span class="line"><!---->  double min = kMinInt;<!----></span><br>  // And-ing any two values results in a value no larger than their maximum.<span class="line"><!---->  // And-ing any two values results in a value no larger than their maximum.<!----></span><br>  // Even no larger than their minimum if both values are non-negative.<span class="line"><!---->  // Even no larger than their minimum if both values are non-negative.<!----></span><br>  double max =<span class="line"><!---->  double max =<!----></span><br>      lmin >= 0 && rmin >= 0 ? std::min(lmax, rmax) : std::max(lmax, rmax);<span class="line"><!---->      lmin &gt;= 0 &amp;&amp; rmin &gt;= 0 ? std::min(lmax, rmax) : std::max(lmax, rmax);<!----></span><br>  // And-ing with a non-negative value x causes the result to be between<span class="line"><!---->  // And-ing with a non-negative value x causes the result to be between<!----></span><br>  // zero and x.<span class="line"><!---->  // zero and x.<!----></span><br>  if (lmin >= 0) {<span class="line"><!---->  if (lmin &gt;= 0) {<!----></span><br>    min = 0;<span class="line"><!---->    min = 0;<!----></span><br>    max = std::min(max, lmax);<span class="line"><!---->    max = std::min(max, lmax);<!----></span><br>  }<span class="line"><!---->  }<!----></span><br>  if (rmin >= 0) {<span class="line"><!---->  if (rmin &gt;= 0) {<!----></span><br>    min = 0;<span class="line"><!---->    min = 0;<!----></span><br>    max = std::min(max, rmax);<span class="line"><!---->    max = std::min(max, rmax);<!----></span><br>  }<span class="line"><!---->  }<!----></span><br>  return Type::Range(min, max, zone());<span class="line"><!---->  return Type::Range(min, max, zone());<!----></span><br>}<span class="line"><!---->}<!----></span><br>```<span class="line"><!---->```<!----></span><br><br>If we do this for both `x` *and* `y`, then we have a result of `lmax = rmax = 0`, which results in `max = 0` in the above code; but as the value for `x&y` that's miscalculated is `1`, we still break range-tracking.<span class="line"><!---->If we do this for both `x` *and* `y`, then we have a result of `lmax = rmax = 0`, which results in `max = 0` in the above code; but as the value for `x&amp;y` that's miscalculated is `1`, we still break range-tracking.<!----></span><br><br>However, one last obstacle remains: the type propagation to the additions and subtracions only happens during the LoadElimination phase; the `BitwiseAnd` however is only given a type once during the initial Typer phase; we can't use the typed optimization again as there is no equivalent "SpeculativeNumberAnd".<span class="line"><!---->However, one last obstacle remains: the type propagation to the additions and subtracions only happens during the LoadElimination phase; the `BitwiseAnd` however is only given a type once during the initial Typer phase; we can't use the typed optimization again as there is no equivalent "SpeculativeNumberAnd".<!----></span><br>So we need to somehow take the bounds information from the later LoadElimination phase and make it available already during the earlier Typer phase.<span class="line"><!---->So we need to somehow take the bounds information from the later LoadElimination phase and make it available already during the earlier Typer phase.<!----></span><br><br>Time-traveling bounds information<span class="line"><!---->Time-traveling bounds information<!----></span><br>---------------------------------<span class="line"><!---->---------------------------------<!----></span><br><br>It seems impossible for the information that we have gained about a node during the LoadElimination phase to influence the type of that node during the earlier Typer phase.<span class="line"><!---->It seems impossible for the information that we have gained about a node during the LoadElimination phase to influence the type of that node during the earlier Typer phase.<!----></span><br>But fortunately, we don't actually have to learn anything new *about that node*, we can instead add some additional operations that force the type we want during the initial Typer phase, and then use our additional later knowledge to optimize away those operations.<span class="line"><!---->But fortunately, we don't actually have to learn anything new *about that node*, we can instead add some additional operations that force the type we want during the initial Typer phase, and then use our additional later knowledge to optimize away those operations.<!----></span><br><br>For example, consider using `Math.min(0, x)`.<span class="line"><!---->For example, consider using `Math.min(0, x)`.<!----></span><br>The typer knows that this value is less than or equal to zero; and we would hope that the `Select` with condition `0<x` just gets optimized away later.<span class="line"><!---->The typer knows that this value is less than or equal to zero; and we would hope that the `Select` with condition `0&lt;x` just gets optimized away later.<!----></span><br>Unfortunately, this is not the case - the constant folder simply doesn't run after the time where we have gained the knowledge that `x <= 0` (this is probably the only time I will ever be annoyed about the constant folder *not* deleting stuff away).<span class="line"><!---->Unfortunately, this is not the case - the constant folder simply doesn't run after the time where we have gained the knowledge that `x &lt;= 0` (this is probably the only time I will ever be annoyed about the constant folder *not* deleting stuff away).<!----></span><br><br>But instead, consider `Math.min(2**32-1, x+(2**32-1)) - (2**32-1)`.<span class="line"><!---->But instead, consider `Math.min(2**32-1, x+(2**32-1)) - (2**32-1)`.<!----></span><br>Here the SimplifiedLowering-phase can use the knowledge about `x <= 0` to convert the first addition into an (unchecked) `Int32Add` treating the result as an unsigned 32-bit integer, as no overflow can happen.<span class="line"><!---->Here the SimplifiedLowering-phase can use the knowledge about `x &lt;= 0` to convert the first addition into an (unchecked) `Int32Add` treating the result as an unsigned 32-bit integer, as no overflow can happen.<!----></span><br>But the unsigned comparison `2**32-1 < c` for `c` of `uint32`-type *can* actually be optimized away to `false` by the MachineOperatorReducer:<span class="line"><!---->But the unsigned comparison `2**32-1 &lt; c` for `c` of `uint32`-type *can* actually be optimized away to `false` by the MachineOperatorReducer:<!----></span><br><br>```<span class="line"><!---->```<!----></span><br>    case IrOpcode::kUint32LessThan: {<span class="line"><!---->    case IrOpcode::kUint32LessThan: {<!----></span><br>      Uint32BinopMatcher m(node);<span class="line"><!---->      Uint32BinopMatcher m(node);<!----></span><br>      if (m.left().Is(kMaxUInt32)) return ReplaceBool(false);  // M < x => false<span class="line"><!---->      if (m.left().Is(kMaxUInt32)) return ReplaceBool(false);  // M &lt; x =&gt; false<!----></span><br>```<span class="line"><!---->```<!----></span><br><br>This also results in the select being eliminated; the resulting expression `(x+(2**32-1)) - (2**32-1)` (where everything gets lowered to 32-bit operations) can eventually be reduced to just `x` by the MachineOperatorReducer (this optimization requires the fact that `x+(2**32-1)` is used nowhere else; this requirement destroys some other approaches to the problem).<span class="line"><!---->This also results in the select being eliminated; the resulting expression `(x+(2**32-1)) - (2**32-1)` (where everything gets lowered to 32-bit operations) can eventually be reduced to just `x` by the MachineOperatorReducer (this optimization requires the fact that `x+(2**32-1)` is used nowhere else; this requirement destroys some other approaches to the problem).<!----></span><br><br>Thus, none of the operations interfere with the buggy optimization being performed.<span class="line"><!---->Thus, none of the operations interfere with the buggy optimization being performed.<!----></span><br>But during the Typer phase, the additional `Math.min` has an effect: The typer learns that its result can be at most `2**32-1`, and the subtraction can't be positive.<span class="line"><!---->But during the Typer phase, the additional `Math.min` has an effect: The typer learns that its result can be at most `2**32-1`, and the subtraction can't be positive.<!----></span><br><br>In effect, both inputs to the `BitwiseAnd`-node now have a type of `Range(..., 0)`, so the `BitwiseAnd` itself also gets a non-positive type, which is violated by the miscomputed result of `1`.<span class="line"><!---->In effect, both inputs to the `BitwiseAnd`-node now have a type of `Range(..., 0)`, so the `BitwiseAnd` itself also gets a non-positive type, which is violated by the miscomputed result of `1`.<!----></span><br>To get a constant type of `Range(0, 0)` with a value that is actually `-1`, we can first take the maximum with `-1`, then negate and right-shift by `31`.<span class="line"><!---->To get a constant type of `Range(0, 0)` with a value that is actually `-1`, we can first take the maximum with `-1`, then negate and right-shift by `31`.<!----></span><br>The complete PoC for breaking Bounds tracking is:<span class="line"><!---->The complete PoC for breaking Bounds tracking is:<!----></span><br><br>```<span class="line"><!---->```<!----></span><br>function bar(a, arg_true) {<span class="line"><!---->function bar(a, arg_true) {<!----></span><br>    let o = {c0: 0, cf: false};<span class="line"><!---->    let o = {c0: 0, cf: false};<!----></span><br>    let x = ((a&5)==2)|0;<span class="line"><!---->    let x = ((a&amp;5)==2)|0;<!----></span><br>    let y = ((a&6)==1)|0;<span class="line"><!---->    let y = ((a&amp;6)==1)|0;<!----></span><br>    <span class="line"><!---->    <!----></span><br>    "a"[x];"a"[y]; // generate CheckBounds()<span class="line"><!---->    "a"[x];"a"[y]; // generate CheckBounds()<!----></span><br><br>    x = x + (o.cf ? "" : (2**30) - (o.c0&1)) - (2**30); // type is Range(-1,0), but only after LoadElimination<span class="line"><!---->    x = x + (o.cf ? "" : (2**30) - (o.c0&amp;1)) - (2**30); // type is Range(-1,0), but only after LoadElimination<!----></span><br>    y = y + (o.cf ? "" : (2**30) - (o.c0&1)) - (2**30);<span class="line"><!---->    y = y + (o.cf ? "" : (2**30) - (o.c0&amp;1)) - (2**30);<!----></span><br>    <span class="line"><!---->    <!----></span><br>    x = Math.min(2**32-1, x + (2**32-1)) - (2**32-1); // type is Range(-1,0) already during Typer<span class="line"><!---->    x = Math.min(2**32-1, x + (2**32-1)) - (2**32-1); // type is Range(-1,0) already during Typer<!----></span><br>    y = Math.min(2**32-1, y + (2**32-1)) - (2**32-1);<span class="line"><!---->    y = Math.min(2**32-1, y + (2**32-1)) - (2**32-1);<!----></span><br>    let confused = Math.max(-1,x & y); // type is Range(..., 0), really is 1<span class="line"><!---->    let confused = Math.max(-1,x &amp; y); // type is Range(..., 0), really is 1<!----></span><br>    confused = Math.max(-1, confused); // type is Range(-1, 0), really is 1<span class="line"><!---->    confused = Math.max(-1, confused); // type is Range(-1, 0), really is 1<!----></span><br>    confused = ((0-confused)>>31); // type is Range(0, 0), really is -1<span class="line"><!---->    confused = ((0-confused)&gt;&gt;31); // type is Range(0, 0), really is -1<!----></span><br>    return confused;<span class="line"><!---->    return confused;<!----></span><br>}<span class="line"><!---->}<!----></span><br><br>console.log(bar(3, true));<span class="line"><!---->console.log(bar(3, true));<!----></span><br>for (var i = 0; i < 3*10**4; i+=1) bar(0,true);<span class="line"><!---->for (var i = 0; i &lt; 3*10**4; i+=1) bar(0,true);<!----></span><br>console.log(bar(3,true));<span class="line"><!---->console.log(bar(3,true));<!----></span><br>```<span class="line"><!---->```<!----></span><br><br>Typer hardening bypass<span class="line"><!---->Typer hardening bypass<!----></span><br>----------------------<span class="line"><!---->----------------------<!----></span><br><br>I submitted a typer hardening bypass with another simultaneously reported bug (<span class="line"><!---->I submitted a typer hardening bypass with another simultaneously reported bug (<!----></span>issue #1234764<a class="strike-through" target="_blank" href="/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1234764" title="v8/Turbofan: Invalid rotate-right optimization + Typer hardening bypass"><!---->issue #1234764<!----></a>) that can be used to obtain arbitrary code execution for this bug as well.<span class="line"><!---->) that can be used to obtain arbitrary code execution for this bug as well.<!----></span><br>The attached PoC demonstrates that code execution is achievable; for details see the other bug report.<span class="line"><!---->The attached PoC demonstrates that code execution is achievable; for details see the other bug report.<!----></span><br><br><br>#### Please briefly explain who can exploit the vulnerability, and what they gain when doing so<span class="line"><!---->#### Please briefly explain who can exploit the vulnerability, and what they gain when doing so<!----></span><br><br>An attacker running a malicious website can get arbitrary code execution in the context of Chrome's renderer process.<span class="line"><!---->An attacker running a malicious website can get arbitrary code execution in the context of Chrome's renderer process.<!----></span><br><br><br>---<span class="line"><!---->---<!----></span><br><br>### The cause<span class="line"><!---->### The cause<!----></span><br><br><br>#### What version of Chrome have you found the security issue in?<span class="line"><!---->#### What version of Chrome have you found the security issue in?<!----></span><br><br>Chromium 92.0.4515.107 Arch Linux / v8 on current main branch<span class="line"><!---->Chromium 92.0.4515.107 Arch Linux / v8 on current main branch<!----></span><br><br><br>#### Is the security issue related to a crash?<span class="line"><!---->#### Is the security issue related to a crash?<!----></span><br><br>No<span class="line"><!---->No<!----></span><br><br><br>#### Choose the type of vulnerability<span class="line"><!---->#### Choose the type of vulnerability<!----></span><br><br>Remote Code Execution (RCE)<span class="line"><!---->Remote Code Execution (RCE)<!----></span><br><br><br>#### Please provide your credit information<span class="line"><!---->#### Please provide your credit information<!----></span><br><br>Manfred Paul (@_manfp)<span class="line"><!---->Manfred Paul (@_manfp)<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        <div>
          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1234770#c2">Comment 2<!----></a>

        *** Boilerplate reminders! ***<span class="line"><!---->*** Boilerplate reminders! ***<!----></span><br>Please do NOT publicly disclose details until a fix has been released to all our users. Early public disclosure may cancel the provisional reward. Also, please be considerate about disclosure when the bug affects a core library that may be used by other products. Please do NOT share this information with third parties who are not directly involved in fixing the bug. Doing so may cancel the provisional reward. Please be honest if you have already disclosed anything publicly or to third parties. Lastly, we understand that some of you are not interested in money. We offer the option to donate your reward to an eligible charity. If you prefer this option, let us know and we will also match your donation - subject to our discretion. Any rewards that are unclaimed after 12 months will be donated to a charity of our choosing.<span class="line"><!---->Please do NOT publicly disclose details until a fix has been released to all our users. Early public disclosure may cancel the provisional reward. Also, please be considerate about disclosure when the bug affects a core library that may be used by other products. Please do NOT share this information with third parties who are not directly involved in fixing the bug. Doing so may cancel the provisional reward. Please be honest if you have already disclosed anything publicly or to third parties. Lastly, we understand that some of you are not interested in money. We offer the option to donate your reward to an eligible charity. If you prefer this option, let us know and we will also match your donation - subject to our discretion. Any rewards that are unclaimed after 12 months will be donated to a charity of our choosing.<!----></span><br><br>Please contact <span class="line"><!---->Please contact <!----></span>security-vrp@chromium.org<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="mailto:security-vrp@chromium.org"><!---->security-vrp@chromium.org<!----></a> with any questions.<span class="line"><!----> with any questions.<!----></span><br>******************************<span class="line"><!---->******************************<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

      ---<span class="line"><!---->---<!----></span><br><br>### Report description<span class="line"><!---->### Report description<!----></span><br><br><br>v8/Turbofan: Wrong optimization of bitfield checks<span class="line"><!---->v8/Turbofan: Wrong optimization of bitfield checks<!----></span><br><br><br>---<span class="line"><!---->---<!----></span><br><br>### Bug location<span class="line"><!---->### Bug location<!----></span><br><br><br>#### Which product or website have you found a vulnerability in?<span class="line"><!---->#### Which product or website have you found a vulnerability in?<!----></span><br><br>Google Chrome<span class="line"><!---->Google Chrome<!----></span><br><br><br>---<span class="line"><!---->---<!----></span><br><br>### The problem<span class="line"><!---->### The problem<!----></span><br><br><br>#### Please describe the technical details of the vulnerability<span class="line"><!---->#### Please describe the technical details of the vulnerability<!----></span><br><br>Tested on:<span class="line"><!---->Tested on:<!----></span><br>==========<span class="line"><!---->==========<!----></span><br><br> - Chromium 92.0.4515.107 Arch Linux (other platforms affected too)<span class="line"><!----> - Chromium 92.0.4515.107 Arch Linux (other platforms affected too)<!----></span><br> - v8/d8 on current main branch on Linux<span class="line"><!----> - v8/d8 on current main branch on Linux<!----></span><br> <span class="line"><!----> <!----></span><br>Test case:<span class="line"><!---->Test case:<!----></span><br>==========<span class="line"><!---->==========<!----></span><br><br>Execute the following snippet in Chrome's Javascript console or d8:<span class="line"><!---->Execute the following snippet in Chrome's Javascript console or d8:<!----></span><br>```<span class="line"><!---->```<!----></span><br>function foo(a) {<span class="line"><!---->function foo(a) {<!----></span><br>    return ((a & 1) == 1) & ((a & 2) == 1);<span class="line"><!---->    return ((a &amp; 1) == 1) &amp; ((a &amp; 2) == 1);<!----></span><br>}<span class="line"><!---->}<!----></span><br><br>console.log(foo(1));<span class="line"><!---->console.log(foo(1));<!----></span><br>for (var i = 0; i < 3e4; i++) foo(1);<span class="line"><!---->for (var i = 0; i &lt; 3e4; i++) foo(1);<!----></span><br>console.log(foo(1));<span class="line"><!---->console.log(foo(1));<!----></span><br><br>```<span class="line"><!---->```<!----></span><br><br>The expected behavior is to print "0" twice; in reality "0" and "1" are printed.<span class="line"><!---->The expected behavior is to print "0" twice; in reality "0" and "1" are printed.<!----></span><br>This bug can be used to construct mis-typed values, and using a typer hardening bypass (that I simultaneously submitted with a different bug) to achieve arbitrary code execution.<span class="line"><!---->This bug can be used to construct mis-typed values, and using a typer hardening bypass (that I simultaneously submitted with a different bug) to achieve arbitrary code execution.<!----></span><br><br>Root Cause:<span class="line"><!---->Root Cause:<!----></span><br>===========<span class="line"><!---->===========<!----></span><br><br>v8/turbofan's MachineOperatorReducer (`src/compiler/machine-operator-reducer.cc` in v8) contains logic to detect bitfield-comparisons of the form `(x & A) == B` (and additionally `(x >> A) & 1`) and combine multiple of those checks into one.<span class="line"><!---->v8/turbofan's MachineOperatorReducer (`src/compiler/machine-operator-reducer.cc` in v8) contains logic to detect bitfield-comparisons of the form `(x &amp; A) == B` (and additionally `(x &gt;&gt; A) &amp; 1`) and combine multiple of those checks into one.<!----></span><br>Consider the detection logic for the former pattern (around line 1730 of `machine-operator-reducer.cc`):<span class="line"><!---->Consider the detection logic for the former pattern (around line 1730 of `machine-operator-reducer.cc`):<!----></span><br><br>```<span class="line"><!---->```<!----></span><br>  static base::Optional<BitfieldCheck> Detect(Node* node) {<span class="line"><!---->  static base::Optional&lt;BitfieldCheck&gt; Detect(Node* node) {<!----></span><br>    // There are two patterns to check for here:<span class="line"><!---->    // There are two patterns to check for here:<!----></span><br>    // 1. Single-bit checks: `(val >> shift) & 1`, where:<span class="line"><!---->    // 1. Single-bit checks: `(val &gt;&gt; shift) &amp; 1`, where:<!----></span><br>    //    - the shift may be omitted, and/or<span class="line"><!---->    //    - the shift may be omitted, and/or<!----></span><br>    //    - the result may be truncated from 64 to 32<span class="line"><!---->    //    - the result may be truncated from 64 to 32<!----></span><br>    // 2. Equality checks: `(val & mask) == expected`, where:<span class="line"><!---->    // 2. Equality checks: `(val &amp; mask) == expected`, where:<!----></span><br>    //    - val may be truncated from 64 to 32 before masking (see<span class="line"><!---->    //    - val may be truncated from 64 to 32 before masking (see<!----></span><br>    //      ReduceWord32EqualForConstantRhs)<span class="line"><!---->    //      ReduceWord32EqualForConstantRhs)<!----></span><br>    if (node->opcode() == IrOpcode::kWord32Equal) {<span class="line"><!---->    if (node-&gt;opcode() == IrOpcode::kWord32Equal) {<!----></span><br>      Uint32BinopMatcher eq(node);<span class="line"><!---->      Uint32BinopMatcher eq(node);<!----></span><br>      if (eq.left().IsWord32And()) {<span class="line"><!---->      if (eq.left().IsWord32And()) {<!----></span><br>        Uint32BinopMatcher mand(eq.left().node());<span class="line"><!---->        Uint32BinopMatcher mand(eq.left().node());<!----></span><br>        if (mand.right().HasResolvedValue() && eq.right().HasResolvedValue()) {<span class="line"><!---->        if (mand.right().HasResolvedValue() &amp;&amp; eq.right().HasResolvedValue()) {<!----></span><br>          BitfieldCheck result{mand.left().node(), mand.right().ResolvedValue(),<span class="line"><!---->          BitfieldCheck result{mand.left().node(), mand.right().ResolvedValue(),<!----></span><br>                               eq.right().ResolvedValue(), false};<span class="line"><!---->                               eq.right().ResolvedValue(), false};<!----></span><br>          if (mand.left().IsTruncateInt64ToInt32()) {<span class="line"><!---->          if (mand.left().IsTruncateInt64ToInt32()) {<!----></span><br>                ...<span class="line"><!---->                ...<!----></span><br>          }<span class="line"><!---->          }<!----></span><br>          return result;<span class="line"><!---->          return result;<!----></span><br>        }<span class="line"><!---->        }<!----></span><br>      }<span class="line"><!---->      }<!----></span><br>    } else {<span class="line"><!---->    } else {<!----></span><br>        ...<span class="line"><!---->        ...<!----></span><br>    }<span class="line"><!---->    }<!----></span><br>    return {};<span class="line"><!---->    return {};<!----></span><br>  }<span class="line"><!---->  }<!----></span><br>```<span class="line"><!---->```<!----></span><br><br>Here, checks of the form `(x & A) == B` with `A, B` constant are detected.<span class="line"><!---->Here, checks of the form `(x &amp; A) == B` with `A, B` constant are detected.<!----></span><br>Note that there is no check that the check is actually satisfiable, i.e. that every set bit of A is also set in B.<span class="line"><!---->Note that there is no check that the check is actually satisfiable, i.e. that every set bit of A is also set in B.<!----></span><br><br>At each `Word32And`-node where both inputs are detected as `BitfieldCheck`s, both checks are combined:<span class="line"><!---->At each `Word32And`-node where both inputs are detected as `BitfieldCheck`s, both checks are combined:<!----></span><br><br>```<span class="line"><!---->```<!----></span><br>  base::Optional<BitfieldCheck> TryCombine(const BitfieldCheck& other) {<span class="line"><!---->  base::Optional&lt;BitfieldCheck&gt; TryCombine(const BitfieldCheck&amp; other) {<!----></span><br>    if (source != other.source ||<span class="line"><!---->    if (source != other.source ||<!----></span><br>        truncate_from_64_bit != other.truncate_from_64_bit)<span class="line"><!---->        truncate_from_64_bit != other.truncate_from_64_bit)<!----></span><br>      return {};<span class="line"><!---->      return {};<!----></span><br>    uint32_t overlapping_bits = mask & other.mask;<span class="line"><!---->    uint32_t overlapping_bits = mask &amp; other.mask;<!----></span><br>    // It would be kind of strange to have any overlapping bits, but they can be<span class="line"><!---->    // It would be kind of strange to have any overlapping bits, but they can be<!----></span><br>    // allowed as long as they don't require opposite values in the same<span class="line"><!---->    // allowed as long as they don't require opposite values in the same<!----></span><br>    // positions.<span class="line"><!---->    // positions.<!----></span><br>    if ((masked_value & overlapping_bits) !=<span class="line"><!---->    if ((masked_value &amp; overlapping_bits) !=<!----></span><br>        (other.masked_value & overlapping_bits))<span class="line"><!---->        (other.masked_value &amp; overlapping_bits))<!----></span><br>      return {};<span class="line"><!---->      return {};<!----></span><br>    return BitfieldCheck{source, mask | other.mask,<span class="line"><!---->    return BitfieldCheck{source, mask | other.mask,<!----></span><br>                         masked_value | other.masked_value,<span class="line"><!---->                         masked_value | other.masked_value,<!----></span><br>                         truncate_from_64_bit};<span class="line"><!---->                         truncate_from_64_bit};<!----></span><br>  }<span class="line"><!---->  }<!----></span><br>```<span class="line"><!---->```<!----></span><br><br>Here, there is a check that the bits that are contained in both masks are actually compared to the same value; but there is no check that each individual check is satsifiable.<span class="line"><!---->Here, there is a check that the bits that are contained in both masks are actually compared to the same value; but there is no check that each individual check is satsifiable.<!----></span><br>By or-ing together both `mask`s and `masked_value`s, the information of which "and" requires each bit to be set is lost, which can lead to the combination of an unsatisfiable check with another check to be satisfiable.<span class="line"><!---->By or-ing together both `mask`s and `masked_value`s, the information of which "and" requires each bit to be set is lost, which can lead to the combination of an unsatisfiable check with another check to be satisfiable.<!----></span><br>The simplest example (in the absence of other optimizations like constant folding) is `((x & 0) == 1) & ((x & 1) == 1)` - as the masks `0` and `1` don't share set bits, the `overlapping_bits`-check is passed, and the checks are combined to `(x & 1) == 1`; this is clearly not equivalent as `(x & 0) == 1` is obviously not satisfiable while `(x & 1) == 1` is.<span class="line"><!---->The simplest example (in the absence of other optimizations like constant folding) is `((x &amp; 0) == 1) &amp; ((x &amp; 1) == 1)` - as the masks `0` and `1` don't share set bits, the `overlapping_bits`-check is passed, and the checks are combined to `(x &amp; 1) == 1`; this is clearly not equivalent as `(x &amp; 0) == 1` is obviously not satisfiable while `(x &amp; 1) == 1` is.<!----></span><br><br>We can even combine two unsatisfiable checks into a satisfiable one: For example, `((x & 1) == 2) & ((x & 2) == 1)` gets combined to `(x & 3) == 3`.<span class="line"><!---->We can even combine two unsatisfiable checks into a satisfiable one: For example, `((x &amp; 1) == 2) &amp; ((x &amp; 2) == 1)` gets combined to `(x &amp; 3) == 3`.<!----></span><br><br>Fix:<span class="line"><!---->Fix:<!----></span><br>====<span class="line"><!---->====<!----></span><br><br>The bug can be fixed by introducing an additional check either during the detection or during the combination of bitfield checks.<span class="line"><!---->The bug can be fixed by introducing an additional check either during the detection or during the combination of bitfield checks.<!----></span><br>It seems reasonable to do the former and require that `BitfieldCheck`s never have bits set in the `masked_value` that aren't set in `mask`.<span class="line"><!---->It seems reasonable to do the former and require that `BitfieldCheck`s never have bits set in the `masked_value` that aren't set in `mask`.<!----></span><br>A suggested patch for this is attached as `machine-operator-reducer.cc.patch`.<span class="line"><!---->A suggested patch for this is attached as `machine-operator-reducer.cc.patch`.<!----></span><br><br>Exploitation:<span class="line"><!---->Exploitation:<!----></span><br>=============<span class="line"><!---->=============<!----></span><br><br>The rest of this write-up will describe how exactly the bug was triggered in a way that causes a type confusion, and how this type confusion can be leveraged into arbitrary code exeuction using a new typer-hardening bypass.<span class="line"><!---->The rest of this write-up will describe how exactly the bug was triggered in a way that causes a type confusion, and how this type confusion can be leveraged into arbitrary code exeuction using a new typer-hardening bypass.<!----></span><br>A full PoC that executes a customizable shellcode (in the example, for Linux x64) is attached as `bitfield_rce.js`.<span class="line"><!---->A full PoC that executes a customizable shellcode (in the example, for Linux x64) is attached as `bitfield_rce.js`.<!----></span><br>It can either be run with a current version of `d8` or embedded into a html file openened with `chrome --no-sandbox` (however the example shellcode has no observable effect when run in Chrome's renderer; there doesn't seem to be an easy portable way to pop a calc on Linux :( ).<span class="line"><!---->It can either be run with a current version of `d8` or embedded into a html file openened with `chrome --no-sandbox` (however the example shellcode has no observable effect when run in Chrome's renderer; there doesn't seem to be an easy portable way to pop a calc on Linux :( ).<!----></span><br><br>There are some significant difficulties when trying to convert this bug into a mis-typed value, but it can be done.<span class="line"><!---->There are some significant difficulties when trying to convert this bug into a mis-typed value, but it can be done.<!----></span><br>The basic idea is to see the two checks as two abstract values `x` and `y` that satisfy `x == 0` and `y == 0`, but also `(x&y) == 1`, and use this to break the Typer's logic (while the checks actually have `Boolean`-typed results, here we treat them as integers - we can simply use `let x = check|0` to do the conversion, which gets optimized away by `MachineOperatorReducer` and doesn't interfere with the bug).<span class="line"><!---->The basic idea is to see the two checks as two abstract values `x` and `y` that satisfy `x == 0` and `y == 0`, but also `(x&amp;y) == 1`, and use this to break the Typer's logic (while the checks actually have `Boolean`-typed results, here we treat them as integers - we can simply use `let x = check|0` to do the conversion, which gets optimized away by `MachineOperatorReducer` and doesn't interfere with the bug).<!----></span><br>The greatest challenge however lies in actually "teaching" the Typer that `x` and `y` are both zero.<span class="line"><!---->The greatest challenge however lies in actually "teaching" the Typer that `x` and `y` are both zero.<!----></span><br><br>The easiest approach would be to write a check that is "obviously" wrong by size-information alone, like `(a & 1) == 42`.<span class="line"><!---->The easiest approach would be to write a check that is "obviously" wrong by size-information alone, like `(a &amp; 1) == 42`.<!----></span><br>Indeed, this gets typed to a constant `false`, as the left side has type `Range(0, 1)` while the right side has type `42`; but unfortunately, this also results in constant folding happening, which destroys the construct needed to trigger the bug.<span class="line"><!---->Indeed, this gets typed to a constant `false`, as the left side has type `Range(0, 1)` while the right side has type `42`; but unfortunately, this also results in constant folding happening, which destroys the construct needed to trigger the bug.<!----></span><br><br>Instead, we have to use checks that are less "obviously" wrong, i.e. where the mask is greater or equal than the right-hand side.<span class="line"><!---->Instead, we have to use checks that are less "obviously" wrong, i.e. where the mask is greater or equal than the right-hand side.<!----></span><br>For example, `(a & 5) == 2` and `(a & 6) == 1` can be used, which are both (unbeknownst to the typer) unsatisfiable, but are combined into `(a & 7) == 3` which is satisfied for `a = 3`.<span class="line"><!---->For example, `(a &amp; 5) == 2` and `(a &amp; 6) == 1` can be used, which are both (unbeknownst to the typer) unsatisfiable, but are combined into `(a &amp; 7) == 3` which is satisfied for `a = 3`.<!----></span><br><br>But now we still need a primitive to "teach" the typer that `x` and `y` are in fact `0`, not `1`.<span class="line"><!---->But now we still need a primitive to "teach" the typer that `x` and `y` are in fact `0`, not `1`.<!----></span><br>However, we need to do so without interfering with the data-flow graph between `x&y` and its inputs `x`a and `y`, as this would destroy the triggering construct.<span class="line"><!---->However, we need to do so without interfering with the data-flow graph between `x&amp;y` and its inputs `x`a and `y`, as this would destroy the triggering construct.<!----></span><br>For example, we can't use `Math.min(0, x)` instead of `x` as this would result in an additional `Select`-node (side note: one should really be able to enclose the rest of the function in a `if (!(0<x)) {...}` and *there* use `Math.min(0, x)`, but due to details of the lowering of `Select`-nodes the two equivalent branches are never actually combined).<span class="line"><!---->For example, we can't use `Math.min(0, x)` instead of `x` as this would result in an additional `Select`-node (side note: one should really be able to enclose the rest of the function in a `if (!(0&lt;x)) {...}` and *there* use `Math.min(0, x)`, but due to details of the lowering of `Select`-nodes the two equivalent branches are never actually combined).<!----></span><br><br>Let's first introduce a very useful primitive:<span class="line"><!---->Let's first introduce a very useful primitive:<!----></span><br><br>Typer-opaque constants<span class="line"><!---->Typer-opaque constants<!----></span><br>----------------------<span class="line"><!---->----------------------<!----></span><br><br>It is useful to have values that unknown to the Typer-phase of the pipeline, but that can be fully reduced to constants during later phases like EarlyOptimization, where `MachineOperatorReducer` is first run.<span class="line"><!---->It is useful to have values that unknown to the Typer-phase of the pipeline, but that can be fully reduced to constants during later phases like EarlyOptimization, where `MachineOperatorReducer` is first run.<!----></span><br>This can be used to introduce uncertainty into types where needed to prevent e.g. constant folding.<span class="line"><!---->This can be used to introduce uncertainty into types where needed to prevent e.g. constant folding.<!----></span><br>This primitive can be obtained using the LoadElimination-phase: We use a local object `o` to hold a constant `c0` equal to zero; whenever we load this constant the typer can speculate that this is a number, but cannot reason about its exact value.<span class="line"><!---->This primitive can be obtained using the LoadElimination-phase: We use a local object `o` to hold a constant `c0` equal to zero; whenever we load this constant the typer can speculate that this is a number, but cannot reason about its exact value.<!----></span><br>During LoadElimination, this is replaced by a constant `0` node, enabling further optimizations.<span class="line"><!---->During LoadElimination, this is replaced by a constant `0` node, enabling further optimizations.<!----></span><br>Note: For unknown reasons, the LoadElimination only seems to work properly when causing the function's optimization with a loop instead of the "%PrepareFunctionForOptimization"/"%OptimizeFunctionOnNextCall" intrinsics.<span class="line"><!---->Note: For unknown reasons, the LoadElimination only seems to work properly when causing the function's optimization with a loop instead of the "%PrepareFunctionForOptimization"/"%OptimizeFunctionOnNextCall" intrinsics.<!----></span><br><br>This primitive can also be used to introduce partially-known types: For example, `(o.c0 & 1)` can be typed to `Range(0, 1)` (and is later constant-folded into `0`).<span class="line"><!---->This primitive can also be used to introduce partially-known types: For example, `(o.c0 &amp; 1)` can be typed to `Range(0, 1)` (and is later constant-folded into `0`).<!----></span><br><br><br>Teaching the typer<span class="line"><!---->Teaching the typer<!----></span><br>------------------<span class="line"><!---->------------------<!----></span><br><br>To actually "teach" the typer about `x` and `y` being zero, a string-indexing operation can be used.<span class="line"><!---->To actually "teach" the typer about `x` and `y` being zero, a string-indexing operation can be used.<!----></span><br>If we access e.g. `"a"[x]`, then a `CheckBounds()` node is generated that checks that `a` lies in `Range(0, 0)` (an array access doesn't work for our purposes, as the array length gets constant-folded too late in the compilation pipeline).<span class="line"><!---->If we access e.g. `"a"[x]`, then a `CheckBounds()` node is generated that checks that `a` lies in `Range(0, 0)` (an array access doesn't work for our purposes, as the array length gets constant-folded too late in the compilation pipeline).<!----></span><br>This seems useless at first because we can't actually use the output of the `CheckBounds`-nodes in our data flow.<span class="line"><!---->This seems useless at first because we can't actually use the output of the `CheckBounds`-nodes in our data flow.<!----></span><br>However, `redundancy-elimination.cc` contains the following optimization:<span class="line"><!---->However, `redundancy-elimination.cc` contains the following optimization:<!----></span><br><br>```<span class="line"><!---->```<!----></span><br>Reduction RedundancyElimination::ReduceSpeculativeNumberOperation(Node* node) {<span class="line"><!---->Reduction // type is Range(0, 0), really is -1<!----></span><br>    return confused;<span class="line"><!---->    return confused;<!----></span><br>}<span class="line"><!---->}<!----></span><br><br>console.log(bar(3, true));<span class="line"><!---->console.log(bar(3, true));<!----></span><br>for (var i = 0; i < 3*10**4; i+=1) bar(0,true);<span class="line"><!---->for (var i = 0; i &lt; 3*10**4; i+=1) bar(0,true);<!----></span><br>console.log(bar(3,true));<span class="line"><!---->console.log(bar(3,true));<!----></span><br>```<span class="line"><!---->```<!----></span><br><br>Typer hardening bypass<span class="line"><!---->Typer hardening bypass<!----></span><br>----------------------<span class="line"><!---->----------------------<!----></span><br><br>I submitted a typer hardening bypass with another simultaneously reported bug (<span class="line"><!---->I submitted a typer hardening bypass with another simultaneously reported bug (<!----></span>issue #1234764<a class="strike-through" target="_blank" href="/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1234764" title="v8/Turbofan: Invalid rotate-right optimization + Typer hardening bypass"><!---->issue #1234764<!----></a>) that can be used to obtain arbitrary code execution for this bug as well.<span class="line"><!---->) that can be used to obtain arbitrary code execution for this bug as well.<!----></span><br>The attached PoC demonstrates that code execution is achievable; for details see the other bug report.<span class="line"><!---->The attached PoC demonstrates that code execution is achievable; for details see the other bug report.<!----></span><br><br><br>#### Please briefly explain who can exploit the vulnerability, and what they gain when doing so<span class="line"><!---->#### Please briefly explain who can exploit the vulnerability, and what they gain when doing so<!----></span><br><br>An attacker running a malicious website can get arbitrary code execution in the context of Chrome's renderer process.<span class="line"><!---->An attacker running a malicious website can get arbitrary code execution in the context of Chrome's renderer process.<!----></span><br><br><br>---<span class="line"><!---->---<!----></span><br><br>### The cause<span class="line"><!---->### The cause<!----></span><br><br><br>#### What version of Chrome have you found the security issue in?<span class="line"><!---->#### What version of Chrome have you found the security issue in?<!----></span><br><br>Chromium 92.0.4515.107 Arch Linux / v8 on current main branch<span class="line"><!---->Chromium 92.0.4515.107 Arch Linux / v8 on current main branch<!----></span><br><br><br>#### Is the security issue related to a crash?<span class="line"><!---->#### Is the security issue related to a crash?<!----></span><br><br>No<span class="line"><!---->No<!----></span><br><br><br>#### Choose the type of vulnerability<span class="line"><!---->#### Choose the type of vulnerability<!----></span><br><br>Remote Code Execution (RCE)<span class="line"><!---->Remote Code Execution (RCE)<!----></span><br><br><br>#### Please provide your credit information<span class="line"><!---->#### Please provide your credit information<!----></span><br><br>Manfred Paul (@_manfp)<span class="line"><!---->Manfred Paul (@_manfp)<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        *** Boilerplate reminders! ***<span class="line"><!---->*** Boilerplate reminders! ***<!----></span><br>Please do NOT publicly disclose details until a fix has been released to all our users. Early public disclosure may cancel the provisional reward. Also, please be considerate about disclosure when the bug affects a core library that may be used by other products. Please do NOT share this information with third parties who are not directly involved in fixing the bug. Doing so may cancel the provisional reward. Please be honest if you have already disclosed anything publicly or to third parties. Lastly, we understand that some of you are not interested in money. We offer the option to donate your reward to an eligible charity. If you prefer this option, let us know and we will also match your donation - subject to our discretion. Any rewards that are unclaimed after 12 months will be donated to a charity of our choosing.<span class="line"><!---->Please do NOT publicly disclose details until a fix has been released to all our users. Early public disclosure may cancel the provisional reward. Also, please be considerate about disclosure when the bug affects a core library that may be used by other products. Please do NOT share this information with third parties who are not directly involved in fixing the bug. Doing so may cancel the provisional reward. Please be honest if you have already disclosed anything publicly or to third parties. Lastly, we understand that some of you are not interested in money. We offer the option to donate your reward to an eligible charity. If you prefer this option, let us know and we will also match your donation - subject to our discretion. Any rewards that are unclaimed after 12 months will be donated to a charity of our choosing.<!----></span><br><br>Please contact <span class="line"><!---->Please contact <!----></span>security-vrp@chromium.org<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="mailto:security-vrp@chromium.org"><!---->security-vrp@chromium.org<!----></a> with any questions.<span class="line"><!----> with any questions.<!----></span><br>******************************<span class="line"><!---->******************************<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

checks"><!---->chromium:1234770<!----></a>, <span class="line"><!---->, <!----></span>chromium:1247763<span class="line"><!---->chromium:1247763<!----></span><br>Change-Id:       ---<span class="line"><!---->---<!----></span><br><br>### Report description<span class="line"><!---->### Report description<!----></span><br><br><br>v8/Turbofan: Wrong optimization of bitfield checks<span class="line"><!---->v8/Turbofan: Wrong optimization of bitfield checks<!----></span><br><br><br>---<span class="line"><!---->---<!----></span><br><br>### Bug location<span class="line"><!---->### Bug location<!----></span><br><br><br>#### Which product or website have you found a vulnerability in?<span class="line"><!---->#### Which product or website have you found a vulnerability in?<!----></span><br><br>Google Chrome<span class="line"><!---->Google Chrome<!----></span><br><br><br>---<span class="line"><!---->---<!----></span><br><br>### The problem<span class="line"><!---->### The problem<!----></span><br><br><br>#### Please describe the technical details of the vulnerability<span class="line"><!---->#### Please describe the technical details of the vulnerability<!----></span><br><br>Tested on:<span class="line"><!---->Tested on:<!----></span><br>==========<span class="line"><!---->==========<!----></span><br><br> - Chromium 92.0.4515.107 Arch Linux (other platforms affected too)<span class="line"><!----> - Chromium 92.0.4515.107 Arch Linux (other platforms affected too)<!----></span><br> - v8/d8 on current main branch on Linux<span class="line"><!----> - v8/d8 on current main branch on Linux<!----></span><br> <span class="line"><!----> <!----></span><br>Test case:<span class="line"><!---->Test case:<!----></span><br>==========<span class="line"><!---->==========<!----></span><br><br>Execute the following snippet in Chrome's Javascript console or d8:<span class="line"><!---->Execute the following snippet in Chrome's Javascript console or d8:<!----></span><br>```<span class="line"><!---->```<!----></span><br>function foo(a) {<span class="line"><!---->function foo(a) {<!----></span><br>    return ((a & 1) == 1) & ((a & 2) == 1);<span class="line"><!---->    return ((a &amp; 1) == 1) &amp; ((a &amp; 2) == 1);<!----></span><br>}<span class="line"><!---->}<!----></span><br><br>console.log(foo(1));<span class="line"><!---->console.log(foo(1));<!----></span><br>for (var i = 0; i < 3e4; i++) foo(1);<span class="line"><!---->for (var i = 0; i &lt; 3e4; i++) foo(1);<!----></span><br>console.log(foo(1));<span class="line"><!---->console.log(foo(1));<!----></span><br><br>```<span class="line"><!---->```<!----></span><br><br>The expected behavior is to print "0" twice; in reality "0" and "1" are printed.<span class="line"><!---->The expected behavior is to print "0" twice; in reality "0" and "1" are printed.<!----></span><br>This bug can be used to construct mis-typed values, and using a typer hardening bypass (that I simultaneously submitted with a different bug) to achieve arbitrary code execution.<span class="line"><!---->This bug can be used to construct mis-typed values, and using a typer hardening bypass (that I simultaneously submitted with a different bug) to achieve arbitrary code execution.<!----></span><br><br>Root Cause:<span class="line"><!---->Root Cause:<!----></span><br>===========<span class="line"><!---->===========<!----></span><br><br>v8/turbofan's MachineOperatorReducer (`src/compiler/machine-operator-reducer.cc` in v8) contains logic to detect bitfield-comparisons of the form `(x & A) == B` (and additionally `(x >> A) & 1`) and combine multiple of those checks into one.<span class="line"><!---->v8/turbofan's MachineOperatorReducer (`src/compiler/machine-operator-reducer.cc` in v8) contains logic to detect bitfield-comparisons of the form `(x &amp; A) == B` (and additionally `(x &gt;&gt; A) &amp; 1`) and combine multiple of those checks into one.<!----></span><br>Consider the detection logic for the former pattern (around line 1730 of `machine-operator-reducer.cc`):<span class="line"><!---->Consider the detection logic for the former pattern (around line 1730 of `machine-operator-reducer.cc`):<!----></span><br><br>```<span class="line"><!---->```<!----></span><br>  static base::Optional<BitfieldCheck> Detect(Node* node) {<span class="line"><!---->  static base::Optional&lt;BitfieldCheck&gt; Detect(Node* node) {<!----></span><br>    // There are two patterns to check for here:<span class="line"><!---->    // There are two patterns to check for here:<!----></span><br>    // 1. Single-bit checks: `(val >> shift) & 1`, where:<span class="line"><!---->    // 1. Single-bit checks: `(val &gt;&gt; shift) &amp; 1`, where:<!----></span><br>    //    - the shift may be omitted, and/or<span class="line"><!---->    //    - the shift may be omitted, and/or<!----></span><br>    //    - the result may be truncated from 64 to 32<span class="line"><!---->    //    - the result may be truncated from 64 to 32<!----></span><br>    // 2. Equality checks: `(val & mask) == expected`, where:<span class="line"><!---->    // 2. Equality checks: `(val &amp; mask) == expected`, where:<!----></span><br>    //    - val may be truncated from 64 to 32 before masking (see<span class="line"><!---->    //    - val may be truncated from 64 to 32 before masking (see<!----></span><br>    //      ReduceWord32EqualForConstantRhs)<span class="line"><!---->    //      ReduceWord32EqualForConstantRhs)<!----></span><br>    if (node->opcode() == IrOpcode::kWord32Equal) {<span class="line"><!---->    if (node-&gt;opcode() == IrOpcode::kWord32Equal) {<!----></span><br>      Uint32BinopMatcher eq(node);<span class="line"><!---->      Uint32BinopMatcher eq(node);<!----></span><br>      if (eq.left().IsWord32And()) {<span class="line"><!---->      if (eq.left().IsWord32And()) {<!----></span><br>        Uint32BinopMatcher mand(eq.left().node());<span class="line"><!---->        Uint32BinopMatcher mand(eq.left().node());<!----></span><br>        if (mand.right().HasResolvedValue() && eq.right().HasResolvedValue()) {<span class="line"><!---->        if (mand.right().HasResolvedValue() &amp;&amp; eq.right().HasResolvedValue()) {<!----></span><br>          BitfieldCheck result{mand.left().node(), mand.right().ResolvedValue(),<span class="line"><!---->          BitfieldCheck result{mand.left().node(), mand.right().ResolvedValue(),<!----></span><br>                               eq.right().ResolvedValue(), false};<span class="line"><!---->                               eq.right().ResolvedValue(), false};<!----></span><br>          if (mand.left().IsTruncateInt64ToInt32()) {<span class="line"><!---->          if (mand.left().IsTruncateInt64ToInt32()) {<!----></span><br>                ...<span class="line"><!---->                ...<!----></span><br>          }<span class="line"><!---->          }<!----></span><br>          return result;<span class="line"><!---->          return result;<!----></span><br>        }<span class="line"><!---->        }<!----></span><br>      }<span class="line"><!---->      }<!----></span><br>    } else {<span class="line"><!---->    } else {<!----></span><br>        ...<span class="line"><!---->        ...<!----></span><br>    }<span class="line"><!---->    }<!----></span><br>    return {};<span class="line"><!---->    return {};<!----></span><br>  }<span class="line"><!---->  }<!----></span><br>```<span class="line"><!---->```<!----></span><br><br>Here, checks of the form `(x & A) == B` with `A, B` constant are detected.<span class="line"><!---->Here, checks of the form `(x &amp; A) == B` with `A, B` constant are detected.<!----></span><br>Note that there is no check that the check is actually satisfiable, i.e. that every set bit of A is also set in B.<span class="line"><!---->Note that there is no check that the check is actually satisfiable, i.e. that every set bit of A is also set in B.<!----></span><br><br>At each `Word32And`-node where both inputs are detected as `BitfieldCheck`s, both checks are combined:<span class="line"><!---->At each `Word32And`-node where both inputs are detected as `BitfieldCheck`s, both checks are combined:<!----></span><br><br>```<span class="line"><!---->```<!----></span><br>  base::Optional<BitfieldCheck> TryCombine(const BitfieldCheck& other) {<span class="line"><!---->  base::Optional&lt;BitfieldCheck&gt; TryCombine(const BitfieldCheck&amp; other) {<!----></span><br>    if (source != other.source ||<span class="line"><!---->    if (source != other.source ||<!----></span><br>        truncate_from_64_bit != other.truncate_from_64_bit)<span class="line"><!---->        truncate_from_64_bit != other.truncate_from_64_bit)<!----></span><br>      return {};<span class="line"><!---->      return {};<!----></span><br>    uint32_t overlapping_bits = mask & other.mask;<span class="line"><!---->    uint32_t overlapping_bits = mask &amp; other.mask;<!----></span><br>    // It would be kind of strange to have any overlapping bits, but they can be<span class="line"><!---->    // It would be kind of strange to have any overlapping bits, but they can be<!----></span><br>    // allowed as long as they don't require opposite values in the same<span class="line"><!---->    // allowed as long as they don't require opposite values in the same<!----></span><br>    // positions.<span class="line"><!---->    // positions.<!----></span><br>    if ((masked_value & overlapping_bits) !=<span class="line"><!---->    if ((masked_value &amp; overlapping_bits) !=<!----></span><br>        (other.masked_value & overlapping_bits))<span class="line"><!---->        (other.masked_value &amp; overlapping_bits))<!----></span><br>      return {};<span class="line"><!---->      return {};<!----></span><br>    return BitfieldCheck{source, mask | other.mask,<span class="line"><!---->    return BitfieldCheck{source, mask | other.mask,<!----></span><br>                         masked_value | other.masked_value,<span class="line"><!---->                         masked_value | other.masked_value,<!----></span><br>                         truncate_from_64_bit};<span class="line"><!---->                         truncate_from_64_bit};<!----></span><br>  }<span class="line"><!---->  }<!----></span><br>```<span class="line"><!---->```<!----></span><br><br>Here, there is a check that the bits that are contained in both masks are actually compared to the same value; but there is no check that each individual check is satsifiable.<span class="line"><!---->Here, there is a check that the bits that are contained in both masks are actually compared to the same value; but there is no check that each individual check is satsifiable.<!----></span><br>By or-ing together both `mask`s and `masked_value`s, the information of which "and" requires each bit to be set is lost, which can lead to the combination of an unsatisfiable check with another check to be satisfiable.<span class="line"><!---->By or-ing together both `mask`s and `masked_value`s, the information of which "and" requires each bit to be set is lost, which can lead to the combination of an unsatisfiable check with another check to be satisfiable.<!----></span><br>The simplest example (in the absence of other optimizations like constant folding) is `((x & 0) == 1) & ((x & 1) == 1)` - as the masks `0` and `1` don't share set bits, the `overlapping_bits`-check is passed, and the checks are combined to `(x & 1) == 1`; this is clearly not equivalent as `(x & 0) == 1` is obviously not satisfiable while `(x & 1) == 1` is.<span class="line"><!---->The simplest example (in the absence of other optimizations like constant folding) is `((x &amp; 0) == 1) &amp; ((x &amp; 1) == 1)` - as the masks `0` and `1` don't share set bits, the `overlapping_bits`-check is passed, and the checks are combined to `(x &amp; 1) == 1`; this is clearly not equivalent as `(x &amp; 0) == 1` is obviously not satisfiable while `(x &amp; 1) == 1` is.<!----></span><br><br>We can even combine two unsatisfiable checks into a satisfiable one: For example, `((x & 1) == 2) & ((x & 2) == 1)` gets combined to `(x & 3) == 3`.<span class="line"><!---->We can even combine two unsatisfiable checks into a satisfiable one: For example, `((x &amp; 1) == 2) &amp; ((x &amp; 2) == 1)` gets combined to `(x &amp; 3) == 3`.<!----></span><br><br>Fix:<span class="line"><!---->Fix:<!----></span><br>====<span class="line"><!---->====<!----></span><br><br>The bug can be fixed by introducing an additional check either during the detection or during the combination of bitfield checks.<span class="line"><!---->The bug can be fixed by introducing an additional check either during the detection or during the combination of bitfield checks.<!----></span><br>It seems reasonable to do the former and require that `BitfieldCheck`s never have bits set in the `masked_value` that aren't set in `mask`.<span class="line"><!---->It seems reasonable to do the former and require that `BitfieldCheck`s never have bits set in the `masked_value` that aren't set in `mask`.<!----></span><br>A suggested patch for this is attached as `machine-operator-reducer.cc.patch`.<span class="line"><!---->A suggested patch for this is attached as `machine-operator-reducer.cc.patch`.<!----></span><br><br>Exploitation:<span class="line"><!---->Exploitation:<!----></span><br>=============<span class="line"><!---->=============<!----></span><br><br>The rest of this write-up will describe how exactly the bug was triggered in a way that causes a type confusion, and how this type confusion can be leveraged into arbitrary code exeuction using a new typer-hardening bypass.<span class="line"><!---->The rest of this write-up will describe how exactly the bug was triggered in a way that causes a type confusion, and how this type confusion can be leveraged into arbitrary code exeuction using a new typer-hardening bypass.<!----></span><br>A full PoC that executes a customizable shellcode (in the example, for Linux x64) is attached as `bitfield_rce.js`.<span class="line"><!---->A full PoC that executes a customizable shellcode (in the example, for Linux x64) is attached as `bitfield_rce.js`.<!----></span><br>It can either be run with a current version of `d8` or embedded into a html file openened with `chrome --no-sandbox` (however the example shellcode has no observable effect when run in Chrome's renderer; there doesn't seem to be an easy portable way to pop a calc on Linux :( ).<span class="line"><!---->It can either be run with a current version of `d8` or embedded into a html file openened with `chrome --no-sandbox` (however the example shellcode has no observable effect when run in Chrome's renderer; there doesn't seem to be an easy portable way to pop a calc on Linux :( ).<!----></span><br><br>There are some significant difficulties when trying to convert this bug into a mis-typed value, but it can be done.<span class="line"><!---->There are some significant difficulties when trying to convert this bug into a mis-typed value, but it can be done.<!----></span><br>The basic idea is to see the two checks as two abstract values `x` and `y` that satisfy `x == 0` and `y == 0`, but also `(x&y) == 1`, and use this to break the Typer's logic (while the checks actually have `Boolean`-typed results, here we treat them as integers - we can simply use `let x = check|0` to do the conversion, which gets optimized away by `MachineOperatorReducer` and doesn't interfere with the bug).<span class="line"><!---->The basic idea is to see the two checks as two abstract values `x` and `y` that satisfy `x == 0` and `y == 0`, but also `(x&amp;y) == 1`, and use this to break the Typer's logic (while the checks actually have `Boolean`-typed results, here we treat them as integers - we can simply use `let x = check|0` to do the conversion, which gets optimized away by `MachineOperatorReducer` and doesn't interfere with the bug).<!----></span><br>The greatest challenge however lies in actually "teaching" the Typer that `x` and `y` are both zero.<span class="line"><!---->The greatest challenge however lies in actually "teaching" the Typer that `x` and `y` are both zero.<!----></span><br><br>The easiest approach would be to write a check that is "obviously" wrong by size-information alone, like `(a & 1) == 42`.<span class="line"><!---->The easiest approach would be to write a check that is "obviously" wrong by size-information alone, like `(a &amp; 1) == 42`.<!----></span><br>Indeed, this gets typed to a constant `false`, as the left side has type `Range(0, 1)` while the right side has type `42`; but unfortunately, this also results in constant folding happening, which destroys the construct needed to trigger the bug.<span class="line"><!---->Indeed, this gets typed to a constant `false`, as the left side has type `Range(0, 1)` while the right side has type `42`; but unfortunately, this also results in constant folding happening, which destroys the construct needed to trigger the bug.<!----></span><br><br>Instead, we have to use checks that are less "obviously" wrong, i.e. where the mask is greater or equal than the right-hand side.<span class="line"><!---->Instead, we have to use checks that are less "obviously" wrong, i.e. where the mask is greater or equal than the right-hand side.<!----></span><br>For example, `(a & 5) == 2` and `(a & 6) == 1` can be used, which are both (unbeknownst to the typer) unsatisfiable, but are combined into `(a & 7) == 3` which is satisfied for `a = 3`.<span class="line"><!---->For example, `(a &amp; 5) == 2` and `(a &amp; 6) == 1` can be used, which are both (unbeknownst to the typer) unsatisfiable, but are combined into `(a &amp; 7) == 3` which is satisfied for `a = 3`.<!----></span><br><br>But now we still need a primitive to "teach" the typer that `x` and `y` are in fact `0`, not `1`.<span class="line"><!---->But now we still need a primitive to "teach" the typer that `x` and `y` are in fact `0`, not `1`.<!----></span><br>However, we need to do so without interfering with the data-flow graph between `x&y` and its inputs `x`a and `y`, as this would destroy the triggering construct.<span class="line"><!---->However, we need to do so without interfering with the data-flow graph between `x&amp;y` and its inputs `x`a and `y`, as this would destroy the triggering construct.<!----></span><br>For example, we can't use `Math.min(0, x)` instead of `x` as this would result in an additional `Select`-node (side note: one should really be able to enclose the rest of the function in a `if (!(0<x)) {...}` and *there* use `Math.min(0, x)`, but due to details of the lowering of `Select`-nodes the two equivalent branches are never actually combined).<span class="line"><!---->For example, we can't use `Math.min(0, x)` instead of `x` as this would result in an additional `Select`-node (side note: one should really be able to enclose the rest of the function in a `if (!(0&lt;x)) {...}` and *there* use `Math.min(0, x)`, but due to details of the lowering of `Select`-nodes the two equivalent branches are never actually combined).<!----></span><br><br>Let's first introduce a very useful primitive:<span class="line"><!---->Let's first introduce a very useful primitive:<!----></span><br><br>Typer-opaque constants<span class="line"><!---->Typer-opaque constants<!----></span><br>----------------------<span class="line"><!---->----------------------<!----></span><br><br>It is useful to have values that unknown to the Typer-phase of the pipeline, but that can be fully reduced to constants during later phases like EarlyOptimization, where `MachineOperatorReducer` is first run.<span class="line"><!---->It is useful to have values that unknown to the Typer-phase of the pipeline, but that can be fully reduced to constants during later phases like EarlyOptimization, where `MachineOperatorReducer` is first run.<!----></span><br>This can be used to introduce uncertainty into types where needed to prevent e.g. constant folding.<span class="line"><!---->This can be used to introduce uncertainty into types where needed to prevent e.g. constant folding.<!----></span><br>This primitive can be obtained using the LoadElimination-phase: We use a local object `o` to hold a constant `c0` equal to zero; whenever we load this constant the typer can speculate that this is a number, but cannot reason about its exact value.<span class="line"><!---->This primitive can be obtained using the LoadElimination-phase: We use a local object `o` to hold a constant `c0` equal to zero; whenever we load this constant the typer can speculate that this is a number, but cannot reason about its exact value.<!----></span><br>During LoadElimination, this is replaced by a constant `0` node, enabling further optimizations.<span class="line"><!---->During LoadElimination, this is replaced by a constant `0` node, enabling further optimizations.<!----></span><br>Note: For unknown reasons, the LoadElimination only seems to work properly when causing the function's optimization with a loop instead of function's optimization with a loop instead of the "%PrepareFunctionForOptimization"/"%OptimizeFunctionOnNextCall" intrinsics.<!----></span><br><br>This primitive can also be used to introduce `Range(0, 0)` for `x`.<span class="line"><!---->To prevent constant folding during the typer, we use the "typer-opaque constants"-trick and initially add `2**30-(c0&amp;1)` instead of `2**30`; this
